definition[0]: used to refer to two or more people or things that have already been mentioned or are already known about
example[0]: Bob and Sue said they wouldn’t be able to come.
example[1]: Ken gave me some flowers. Aren’t they beautiful?
example[2]: They all want to come to the wedding.
definition[1]: used to refer to a particular organization or group of people
example[3]: Where are they going to build the new highway?
example[4]: They’re going to take an X-ray.
definition[2]: used when talking about someone who may be male or female, to avoid saying ‘he or she’
example[5]: If anyone has any information related to the crime, will they please contact the police.
example[6]: Every child, whoever they are, deserves to have a mum and a dad.
explanation[0]: If you want to talk in general about someone, and you do not want to say if the person is male or female, you often use they, them, or their
example[7]: If anyone doesn’t like it, they can leave
example[8]: When a friend upsets you, do you tell them?
example[9]: Someone has left their coat behind
explanation[1]: People do this in order to avoid suggesting that the person can only be male, or to avoid using longer expressions such as 'he or she', 'him or her'
explanation[2]: This use is acceptable and very common in spoken English, and is becoming more acceptable in writing as well
explanation[3]: However, some people consider this use to be incorrect You can sometimes avoid the problem by making the subject plural
example[10]: If people don’t like it, they can leave
example[11]: When friends upset you, do you tell them?
